headerData: Jose Herrera is a Software Engineer.

Jose Herrera also likes to make neat websites

entries.title: Summary
paragraph: Jose Herrera is a seasoned blockchain engineer with a talent for transforming intricate protocols into streamlined solutions. With 7 years of experience mastering Solidity and Web3 technologies, Jose has been a key player in the blockchain revolution, crafting smart contracts and decentralized systems that push the boundaries of what's possible in the digital realm.

A graduate from a top Canadian university, Jose has been making waves in the blockchain world since the early days of Ethereum. From spearheading stealth DeFi protocols to advising innovative startups, he's become the go-to expert for turning ambitious blockchain concepts into robust, functional realities.

Jose's expertise spans the full stack, showcasing a comprehensive skill set that goes beyond blockchain development. He excels in crafting robust testing suites, ensuring code quality and reliability. His talent for software architecture allows him to design scalable and efficient systems that stand the test of time. Jose's technical writing skills shine through in his detailed documentation and planning documents, making complex concepts accessible to both technical and non-technical stakeholders. On the front-end, he's proficient with modern frameworks like React and Next.js, creating seamless user experiences. His database work, covering both SQL and NoSQL solutions, rounds out his full-stack capabilities. In the blockchain realm, Jose is adept with Foundry and other cutting-edge development tools, implementing everything from AI-driven investment funds to on-chain governance systems.

When he's not architecting the future of finance, you might find Jose explaining blockchain to his houseplants or trying to convince his toaster to join a DAO. His passion for decentralization is matched only by his knack for making complex systems accessible to both developers and users alike.

In short, if you're seeking a Senior Web3/Blockchain/Protocol Engineer who can transform your most ambitious blockchain ideas into reliable, efficient code, Jose is the engineer you need. Just don't ask him about the time he tried to create a smart contract for his laundry schedule - some things are better left to traditional methods.

entries.title: Kings of the Cities
paragraph: Conceptualized and developed Kings of The Cities (KOTC), an innovative NFT-based platform representing global city rankings. Implemented smart contracts for minting unique 'King' and 'Queen' NFTs for approximately 350 cities, integrated with DeFi ecosystems for treasury growth, and designed a token yield system with DAO governance. Developed the project website using Solidity and Web3 technologies, implementing features such as the minting process, token yield distribution, and DAO voting mechanisms. Successfully launched the project, opening minting for the top 50 world cities, and planned future developments including real-world partnerships and exclusive experiences for the KOTC community.

entries.title: Business in the Front, Crypto in the Back: How to Be a Blockchain Startup in Fintech
paragraph: This paper details the partnership between Novera, a blockchain startup, and CompanyX, an SME investment firm, in developing innovative financial products using blockchain technology. The focus is on their creation of Long-Short Funds and Long-Short Tokens for bitcoin investing. Jose Herrera, Novera's Lead Blockchain Engineer, plays a key role in this narrative. Described as a twentysomething blockchain enthusiast who moved to Toronto to be part of its blockchain scene, Herrera embodies the company's 'crypto in the back' ethos. He's quoted as saying Novera is 'like a mullet, except it's like we're business in the front, crypto in the back,' encapsulating their approach of maintaining regulatory compliance while innovating with blockchain. Herrera, along with Novera's CTO, leads the development of the Long-Short Tokens, demonstrating his significant contribution to the company's technical implementation of blockchain solutions. His belief in blockchain's potential to democratize finance aligns with Novera's innovative approach in the fintech space.

entries.title: Examining Trustless Interoperability Among Blockchain Fintech Services
paragraph: This research paper, authored by Jose Herrera under the supervision of Ken Barker, explores the development of a decentralized exchange for trustless interoperability between Bitcoin and Ethereum blockchains using atomic swaps. Jose's findings include the design of a two-tier, three-layer architecture that allows users to perform atomic swaps without running full blockchain nodes on their own machines. The solution comprises an exchange server that matches traders and coordinates swap steps, and client applications that control private keys and execute blockchain transactions. Jose identified limitations in the current atomic swap methods, including transaction fees, slow processing times, and potential fraud scenarios. He also noted that the proposed exchange could be improved by implementing an order book system for better liquidity and trader matching. Jose concluded that while the solution addresses many issues with centralized exchanges, some inherent limitations of atomic swaps remain, and further development of a JavaScript-based Bitcoin wallet could potentially allow for a pure web app implementation in the future.

entries.title: University of Calgary students close in on fraud-proof electronic voting system
paragraph: A University of Calgary student, Jose Herrera, and his team are developing a fraud-proof electronic voting system using IBM's Blockchain technology. Inspired by his experience with paper ballots in Canada's 2015 federal election, Herrera aims to create a secure, tamper-proof method for recording votes electronically. The system, mentored by IBM's Ivan Milman, could potentially eliminate controversies like the 'hanging chad' issue in the 2000 U.S. presidential election. While the team plans to test it first on a small scale with university student elections, Herrera believes it could be ready for large-scale implementation by 2019. However, he acknowledges that gaining public trust in an electronic voting system remains a significant challenge. The project highlights the potential for blockchain technology to modernize voting processes and possibly enable new forms of direct democracy.
